Authors: Catherine Elizabeth Newman, Leslie J. Rissler
Title:
Phylogeographic analyses of the southern leopard frog: the
impact of geography and climate on the distribution of genetic lineages
vs.Â subspecies
Keywords:
Rana sphenocephala, Lithobates sphenocephalus,
microsatellites, ND1, systematics
Abstract:
We test the correlation of genetic lineage and subspecies
breaks in the southeastern U.S. and the association of such breaks with
climate, using Rana sphenocephala as a case study, and place our results
in the broader context of the Alabama-Appalachian suture zone
(AL-Appalachian SZ) as identified by Rissler & Smith (2010). We use
genetic and ecological methods to 1) determine if genetic lineages are
coincident with the AL-Appalachian SZ or the subspecies and 2) test the
correlation of major climatic breaks with genetic structure and
morphological variation in R. sphenocephala. We sequenced the ND1 mtDNA
gene in 140 R. sphenocephala samples and genotyped 166 samples at six
microsatellite loci. Bayesian phylogenetic analyses revealed two
distinct lineages: western and eastern, with over 4% sequence
divergence. The geographic distributions of the two lineages are
concordant with the AL-Appalachian SZ but do not correspond to the
ranges of the subspecies based on morphology, which separate peninsular
Florida from the rest of the range. Mantel tests revealed that isolation
by distance and historical barriers to gene flow, rather than climate,
are the major drivers of genetic divergence at neutral loci. Examination
of climate breaks across the Southeast revealed a pattern incongruent
with suture zone hotspots, suggesting that phylogenetic structure has
been driven primarily by historical factors, such as isolation, the
Appalachian Mountains, and the Apalachicola/Chattahoochee/Flint River
Basin. However, climate breaks are consistent with the geographic
distribution of the subspecies of R. sphenocephala, suggesting that
environmental pressures may be driving divergence in morphological
traits that outpaces molecular evolution.
